Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Math 112
I learned how to reach out for help a lot more than what I used to do in high school.
I developed my calculous skills from high school.
I learned about calculus and how to think about problems in a more hollistic way. This class taught me basic calculus techniques.
We learned about the real world uses or calculus, focusing on limits, derivatives, and intergrals.
I was able to regain calculus skills and thinking skills that had become less familiar after not taking math since junior year of high school.
I deepened my understanding of calculus. Lots of derivatives and started on integrals
A better, broader understanding of calculus.

I developed the potential to apply math concepts to problems where it was not immediately evident which math concepts were needed to solve. This class greatly improved my ability to problem solve  and work my way logically through a problem.
I learned about derivatives, their application, limits, and integrals.

This was my first time learning anything about calculus overall. I learned a lot of both skills in solving problems and the theory behind it, which I had never done before in high school. It was great. I really enjoyed taking the class.
This course provided me with the necessary background knowledge for progressing onto higher level math courses.
I learned how to compute limits.
I learned fundamental math skills that will be useful in the future.
I learned a deeper level of calculus than I'd learned in high school.

Strengths: Prof VanDenBoom was great
Weakness: no correlation between homeworks, webassigns, and tests so unclear how to prepare or what skills to target

I think there could be more class engagement with having students work out the problems in class as they taught the new material. That is how muy high school math corses were and I think those were really more engaging.
The class lectures would move a bit slow and there were not enough practice problems which we did independently to make lectures worthwhile.
Weaknesses is that it is a boring course but honestly what can you do. It's gen-ed math 112 there really isn't much.
This course was very fast paced. It did not provide enough time to fully understand topics.
Not enough interactive examples done in class. It felt very lecture based instead of interactive.
Vandenboom was amazing! He explained everything very well, only thing to improve would be more class work, where we got to try thins for ourselves:

Strengths: This course was well organized and the order in which the lessons/concepts were taught made logical sense.
Weaknesses: If I did not have any background in calculus, this course would have moved very quickly and would have been hard to keep up.
Lectures were well planed and Dr. V always sought to answer any questions.

The strengths of this class are that the professors do a good job of supporting the students and there are many ways in which students can get help for issues they have. The weakness is that the explanation in class of certain topics could be improved and the teachers could ask the students more questions about if they understand a topic.

Strengths- Good with office hours and being available for students

Weaknesses- They are very focused on complicated interpretations of theorems and I generally don't like how they don't focus on actual application.

At first, the course was very rocky for me as the material in the book and instructed during class was very different from what we actually did during PSETs but, after a while, the difficulty in class was not lagging as much. Thus, the course became easier to manage. I think it could still continue to improve with the addition of both simple and difficult problems in order to introduce how much depth there is involved in the problems skills we gain.

Strengths- psets and webassigns are actually very helpful
Weaknesses- inconsistencies between professors sometimes causes confusion, review sessions for midterms and finals were not always helpful

It is mostly geared towards those who took the AP path in high school; thus, neglecting IB taught students. It strengths lie mostly in the professor, but I also despise textbook learning and wish the class was more in depth.
There was material with a greater level of difficulty that were not shown in class or during the assignments.
Strengths: well-organized and supportive of student learning. Teaches calculus very well.
Yes
I personally wouldn't just because I felt like it wasn't an engaging environment for me.
Yes I would if he or she needs to learn about calculus.
If a student does not need this level math course to fulfill a major requirement, then I would not recommend this course for the QR requirement.

Yes
It is a great introductory course for calculus, especially to regain skills learned in highschool that may not have been applied for a while.
Yes, especially with Professor VandenBoom.
Yes
Only if the student needed to fulfill a QR credit. Personally, I do not love math, but I think this course does a good job of expressing the value and beauty of calculus.
yes, a good math class to take before 115.
Yes, it is a good foundation of math and is needed for a lot of majors.

If they absolutely need to take it, I would recommend it. Otherwise I would probably tell them to take a different QR because I still don't understand how I can know how to do every problem on the test but still get a not good grade.

I would recommend this course to other students. Although it is a bit difficult and time consuming, there was a lot of knowledge to be gain from the course. It would be beneficial for others who want to study math to get a taste of it.
I would recommend this course to a student who does not have any background in calculus or is not confident in their knowledge of calculus.
nah fam
Yes, because it was taught extremely well and beginner-friendly.
